entry.title: Important Communication to SAP Community Regarding Argentina e-Invoicing legal change and New Contin
entry.content:
Dear SAP users and community members,

SAP shares important information regarding the Argentinean tax authority General Resolution (GR) N¬∞ 5785/2025 and its implications for ERPs in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition variants.

Regulatory Summary

The Argentinean tax authority General Resolution N¬∞ 5785/2025 has established the CAEA method (Anticipated Electronic Authorization Code) as the primary contingency method option (for VAT registered taxpayers ‚ÄúResponsables Inscriptos‚Äù) for issuing Electronic Invoices under the CAE method.

How this LC impacts on Private and OP ERP Systems

Given that the CAEA method is not within the scope of SAP's standard localization for Argentina, for Private and OP ERP Systems, we inform you that the functionality for managing and implementing the CAEA method as a contingency will not be included in the scope of the Argentina localization for our ERP solutions in SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. SAP understands that it has an extensive network of partner services within the SAP ecosystem.

On the other hand, please be informed that for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP plans to include this resolution since CAEA is included in the solution portfolio.

 It is also important to remark, that beside that CAEA option will not be covered by default, there are other contingency options that remain valid in SAP solutions, such as ON LINE and OFF LINE contingency (self-printers ‚Äúautoimpresores‚Äù).

We recommend you review your internal contingency processes and, if necessary, explore complementary solutions that allow for the management of CAEA within the ecosystem of our on-premise ERPs, should this method be mandatory for your company to comply with GR 5785/2025.

For any additional questions regarding the scope of Argentina localization, please visit the SAP Help Portal, or use other established SAP communication channels.

 Thank you for your attention

SAP Globalization
Localization for Argentina

entry.title: RESULTLOOKUP/RESTRICT Not Accepting <=, >=, <, > Operators in SAC
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I believe I have encountered a bug in the SAP Analytics Cloud Formula Editor, both at the model level and within stories.

When creating a calculated measure using functions such as RESULTLOOKUP or RESTRICT, the second parameter (which defines the filter conditions) does not accept comparison operators such as:

  • <=

  • >=

  • <

  • >

Whenever I use one of these operators in the filter block, SAC returns the following error:

‚ÄúFormula could not be computed: Function 'RESULTLOOKUP' expects parameter 2 to be a list of conditions joined with AND. Please complete or rewrite the formula.‚Äù

However, using = or != works fine.

 

Restrict with '='Restrict with '<='Restrict with '<' simple example

This limitation prevents me from implementing formulas that require range-based filters.
For example, I need to create a custom YTD calculation that retrieves values up to a specific period entered through a story parameter.

I also need additional measures that depend on parameters (e.g., current period, inception-to-date, etc.).
I found partial workarounds‚Äîsuch as creating restricted measures in the story using ‚Äúless than or equal‚Äù input controls‚Äîbut this quickly becomes inefficient. Each measure would require its own input control, meaning the customer would need to select the period multiple times, which is not a good user experience.

I also tried using an IF() statement inside a calculated measure, but then I am forced to display the required dimensions in the table, which is not acceptable from a reporting layout perspective.

My starting requirement is to build a report similar to the ‚ÄúBilling Extract for Invoice/Statement‚Äù available in:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud ‚Üí via the app ‚ÄúSchedule Job for Billing‚Äù,

  • SAP S/4HANA on-premise ‚Üí transaction code GJ12.

To replicate the logic in SAC, I need the ability to filter by period ranges using operators such as <=, which is currently failing in the Formula Editor.

Questions

  • Is this a known limitation or bug in SAC?

  • Is there a planned fix?

  • Is there an official workaround that avoids multiple input controls and avoids exposing dimensions in the table?

Thank you in advance for your help,

poklluka.

entry.title: Re: Attachments in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Dear @kaiwen_,

In Public Cloud when you add an attachment for example a PDF to a supplier invoice the binary file is stored in an attachment repository, while SAP stores the business-object linkage/metadata (who/when, BO key, filename/MIME type, repository reference, etc.). SAP‚Äôs docs explicitly describe the model as ‚Äúcontent + metadata stored in the repository‚Äù and discuss repository options for attachment storage

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/9f2f1c9e067645418a20375211e1ea04.html

1. Standard repository

  • SAP documentation for Public Cloud states that the default repository for unstructured content is Document Service in SAP BTP
  • Practically the repository is not inside your Public Cloud database in the way business tables are it‚Äôs a separate content store managed/provisioned alongside your Public Cloud tenant

More details below:

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fe051b8031274f919dae94150971c621.html

2. Third party repository

  • SAP supports integrating an external repository via CMIS and the customer-managed communication scenario SAP_COM_0597
  • SAP Integrating SAP Document Management guidance also references activating the needed communication arrangements including SAP_COM_0597 for SAP BTP Document Management connectivity

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fe051b8031274f919dae94150971c621.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/03414f87d6e14dff9450e20e21632826.html

Attachment Service as the standard attachment handling layer used by Fiori apps:

  • It‚Äôs a reusable Fiori/UI component + backend services that lets apps upload, list, download, delete and in Advanced Attachment Service scenarios, things like check-in/check-out/versioning
  • It orchestrates storage it links the attachment to the business object and calls the repository typically via CMIS to store/retrieve the file content. SAP notes that the attachment service processing leverages the DMS and GOS frameworks and interacts with repositories via CMIS
  • It also enforces some technical constraints for example, SAP states a 100 MB per-file upload limit for Attachment Service usage in certain apps/scenarios

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/e7ff65b0c2c34652995745c9416edc5e.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/74fa9fbfe5ad47529fd8373bab397c36.html

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3591125

In CBC look at configuration activity below (103583) to see which repository is active.

 

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP Screen Personas 3.0 SP20: Enhancements to Flavor Management, BDT Support, and Adaptive Flavors
entry.content:
The latest update to SAP Screen Personas 3.0 with Service Pack 20 (SP20) introduces several powerful enhancements designed to make flavor creation, maintenance, and device-specific adaptation easier and more flexible than ever.
Below is a summary of the key improvements and how they benefit administrators, developers, and flavor builders.

1.  Copy a Flavor to Multiple Target Flavors

The former "Copy to Application ID" option has been enhanced and renamed to "Copy to Application ID or Flavor ID".
With this improvement, you can now copy a source flavor to target flavor. You can also you can apply the same source flavor to several target flavors in a single step, making mass flavor updates faster and more efficient.

When screens or transactions share similar layouts, you can reuse an existing flavor instead of starting from scratch.
For example: If you have a Display flavor and want to create a Change flavor, you can copy the Display flavor, adjust the fields that differ, and quickly finalize the Change version. This ensures consistency and significantly reduces development time.

Prerequisites

  • Personas Administrator role is required

  • Target flavors must already exist (either empty or with changes)

  • Source flavor must not contain an adaptive stack

For more details, refer to  Copy a Flavor to a Different Transaction in the documentation.
 
Additional  Options for BDT app flavors

BDT (Business Data Toolset) transactions often share identical detail screens but have different entry screens.
To support these scenarios,  an additional option has been introduced for BDT app flavors where the entry screen changes can be skipped during the copy process.
This allows flavor updates to be applied efficiently without impacting initial-screen behavior.

2. Adaptive Flavors for Custom Industrial Devices

Administrators can now define their own device list for adaptive flavor creation in SAP GUI for HTML and Slipstream Engine.

Until SP19, the device list was static and maintained exclusively by SAP. With SP20, administrators can register custom industrial devices used within their organization and specify attributes such as device width and pixel ratio. These values determine how an adaptive flavor is rendered for that specific device.  The newly added devices will be available to choose from list of devices while creating new adaptive flavors.

Additionally, in Slipstream Engine,the custom device created by the administrator becomes available in the Device Preview list, allowing designers to preview exactly how a flavor will appear on a custom company device.

Benefits

  • Enables greater flexibility in optimizing the user experience for rugged devices, handheld scanners, industrial tablets, and other specialized hardware.

  • Ensures that flavors are responsive and visually optimized for the intended device landscape.

  • Streamlines the design cycle and reduces trial-and-error.

For more information, see Devices.

3. BDT Mode Enabled by Default

With SP20, BDT Mode is now enabled by default, simplifying setup and configuration.

This means there is no need to manually set the ENABLE_BDT_MODE parameter in /PERSONAS/ADMIN when creating flavors for Business Data Toolset (BDT)‚Äìenabled transactions, such as Business Partner (BP) screens.

To support legacy flavors created without BDT mode enabled, a new parameter‚ÄîDISABLE_BDT_MODE‚Äîhas been introduced.

This ensures that administrators can preserve previous behavior and that legacy BDT flavors continue to function correctly after the SP20 upgrade.

For more information, refer note 2451049

4. Message Toast Support

In SP20 , a new scripting API command has been introduced for displaying non-interactive popup messages in SAP GUI for HTML similar to the "toast message" in SAPUI5.  Scripting API command was available only in slipstream engine with SP19. With this new command, you can now easily implement message toasts for simple scenarios, allowing for streamlined feedback that aligns with SAP Fiori standards. This addition helps enhance user experience by providing subtle, non-disruptive messages in SAP Screen Personas.

Example:  session.utils.showMessageToast("This is a toast message");

How it works

  • Shows a small popup message that disappears after a few seconds.

  • The message stays visible if the user hovers or taps on it.

Conclusion

The SP20 release brings meaningful enhancements that streamline flavor management, improve BDT handling, and provide greater flexibility for device-specific adaptations. Whether you‚Äôre managing complex environments or designing mobile-friendly screens, these features help deliver a more efficient and tailored user experience.

SP20 related notes: : https://me.sap.com/notes/3672078 

 

Learn more about SAP Screen Personas
  • Online training. The best way to learn the basics about SAP Screen Personas (Adapt UI for classic applications) is to take our free training course on the learning.sap.com platform: https://learning.sap.com/courses/adapting-the-ui-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-using-sap-screen-personas
  • Connect with your peers. Every other month, we have a group of customers that gather online to share best practices, demo their flavors, and answer each other‚Äôs questions. Experts from the product team also join to explain how to use the latest functionality. If you are interested in joining, you can sign up online to join the SAP Screen Personas practitioner forum. This will add you to the mailing list for the monthly meeting summaries. Please contact ‚ÄúPeter Spielvogel‚Äú or me directly if you want to join the monthly calls.
  • Product documentation. The SAP Screen Personas documentation, provides more clear , comprehensive and the latest information about the product.

Going forward with SAP Screen Personas

  1. If you are on SP18 or earlier, we recommend you upgrade now, ideally going directly to SP20.
  2. If you are not currently using SAP Screen Personas, why not?
    Worried that we won‚Äôt support it into the future? Don‚Äôt be.      We are supporting SAP Screen Personas functionality through at least 2040.
    Have other concerns about the     roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post.the ability to adapt the UI of classic apps is something important to us.
    Have other concerns about the     roadmap for SAP Screen Personas? See if we answer them in our latest roadmap blog post.
  3. SAP Screen Personas is now available with the Default Installation Stack of SAP S/4HANA 2025, Private Cloud Edition

entry.title: IFRS 18 Explained: What SAP S/4HANA Customers Need to Know Before 2027
entry.content:
Spoiler
 

IFRS 18 introduces one of the biggest changes to financial statement presentation in decades, replacing IAS 1 and redefining how companies structure their Profit and Loss statements. This blog breaks down the new categories, required subtotals, MPM rules, and cash-flow changes in simple, human language ‚Äî and explains how SAP is preparing to support customers across S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition, and On-Premise. With comparative reporting for 2026 and mandatory adoption from 2027, now is the time for finance and IT teams to understand what‚Äôs coming and how to prepare their SAP landscape.

What Is IFRS 18 and Why Is It Important?

IFRS 18 is a brand-new reporting standard released by the IASB. It replaces IAS 1 (Presentation of Financial Statements) and becomes effective on January 1, 2027.

In simple terms, IFRS 18 changes how companies present their Income Statement (P&L) and how they explain their financial performance.

Think of it as a cleaner, more structured way to show:

  • Where money comes from
  • Where it goes
  • What part of the business truly drives performance

The goal is to:

  • Make financial statements easier to understand
  • Improve consistency across companies
  • Increase transparency for investors
  • Make comparison between companies more fair and simple

What‚Äôs Changing in the Profit and Loss Statement? 

IFRS 18 completely reorganizes the Profit and Loss (P&L) structure.
Instead of mixing items together, companies must now classify every income and expense into new categories:

New Mandatory Categories

  • Operating: Day-to-day business activities
  • Investing: Returns or costs related to long-term investments
  • Financing: Borrowings, interest, and funding-related items
  • Income Tax: All tax-related items
  • Discontinued Operations: Business operations that are shut down or sold

New Required Subtotals

Companies must show these subtotals:

  • Operating Profit
  • Profit or Loss Before Financing and Income Tax
  • Profit or Loss

This improves clarity and avoids situations where different companies calculate ‚Äúoperating profit‚Äù differently.

What Are Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs)?

IFRS 18 introduces strict rules for something many companies already do:
show custom KPIs like ‚ÄúAdjusted EBITDA,‚Äù ‚ÄúCore Profit,‚Äù or ‚ÄúUnderlying Margin.‚Äù

These are called Management-Defined Performance Measures (MPMs).

Under IFRS 18, companies MUST:

  • Explain how the measure is calculated
  • Explain why it is useful
  • Provide a reconciliation to an official IFRS subtotal
  • Include this reconciliation in the notes, and it must be audited

This improves trust and transparency around custom metrics that companies use to tell their story.

Changes to the Cash Flow Statement

IFRS 18 also updates IAS 7 (Cash Flow Statements).
Previously, companies had flexibility in classifying certain cash flows.

Under IFRS 18:

  • Dividends paid ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities
  • Interest paid ‚Üí must be shown under Financing activities
  • Interest received ‚Üí must be shown under Investing activities

This eliminates the old ‚Äúchoice-based‚Äù method and brings global consistency.

Impact on Financial Reporting and Disclosure

IFRS 18 affects several areas of financial reporting:

P&L Structure

Companies must reorganize their charts of accounts and reporting hierarchies.

Disclosures and Notes

More detail is required, especially around MPMs, aggregation rules, and reconciliation.

Comparative Reporting

Mandatory disclosure of 2026 figures in the new IFRS 18 structure when reporting for 2027.

What Does This Mean for Companies Using SAP?

SAP is currently analysing the full impact of IFRS 18 and consulting with customers through Customer Engagement Initiatives.

Key areas SAP is reviewing include:

  • Functional areas
  • General Ledger structure
  • Valuation processes
  • Reporting frameworks in S/4HANA
  • Group Reporting layouts
  • Cash-flow classifications
  • Universal Journal (ACDOCA) extensibility

SAP expects to release a formal solution approach by December 2025(as documented in SAP Note-https://me.sap.com/notes/3670330/E) . This guidance is expected to be included in the IFRS 18 updates for SAP Group Reporting as part of the 1SG content package.

The solution may differ across editions:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    ‚Üí Expect more standardized, pre-delivered content
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
    ‚Üí More flexibility with governance
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise
    ‚Üí Potentially greater configurability

SAP will deliver updates through notes, documentation, and future releases.

How Customers Can Prepare Today

Even before SAP finalizes its solution, companies can begin preparing by:

‚úî Reviewing current P&L structures
‚úî Identifying where income/expense items will map under IFRS 18
‚úî Understanding new disclosure requirements
‚úî Reviewing cash-flow classifications
‚úî Collecting internal MPM definitions
‚úî Engaging with SAP through CEI or Customer Influence Requests

Early preparation will make the transition smoother when IFRS 18 becomes mandatory.

Conclusion

IFRS 18 represents a major shift in how companies communicate their financial performance. The new structure, required subtotals, stricter rules for custom KPIs, and updates to cash flow presentation will significantly impact both finance teams and system configurations.

As outlined in SAP Note 3670330, SAP is developing a comprehensive solution targeted for late 2025, with further updates expected as IFRS 18 continues to evolve. In my view, this is the right time for organizations to start understanding the new requirements, assess their current data and reporting structures, and begin preparing their SAP landscapes for a smooth transition.

More updates will come as SAP refines its roadmap ‚Äî stay tuned.

entry.title: Re: Cost center determination logic in Price difference w...
entry.content:
Good day @yKim 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/9d949972f5924be792e8ad5b7871ddfb.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/adbae5bcd5994f159bf2847a11397b61/4d5e9cef91ef46ed8eb75c8d90f32e94.html?locale=en-US

Based on the information you provided, if you don‚Äôt maintain a default cost center or profit center in Manage Default Account Assignments for the price difference GL, then the system attempts to derive it from:

  • Order, Project, or CO assignment if these are available
  • Cost center on the PO or GR if it is available.

If none of those exist, it may fall back to default profit center, which is often derived from the user‚Äôs organisational data, cost center defaults or the company‚Äôs internal dummy profit center.

In your case, even though your screenshot shows you did not assign any default, the inventory line picks the profit center from the material master, while the price difference line (52041000) does not inherit it automatically. Since you did not assign a default account for the cost element, the system resolves the profit center using fallback logic suggesting that you either have a fallback rule or you have created an internal default.

My suggestion is to ensure consistent profit center assignment by using:

  • SSCUI 102639 to define a default profit center for the PRD cost element.
  • Substitution logic through implementing a BAdI if available in your system.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @weronika_niewiora661 
For the BDC assessment (AI role play) you will receive around 30 questions and the questions span all BDC topics that are covered in the learning journey "Exploring SAP Business Data Cloud".  The topics are pretty evenly weighted. When you begin the assessment you will see the scoring rubric which shows the topics that will come up and their respective weightings. Y can expect to have questions fired at you for around 20-25 minutes. When the assessment is over the AI will let you know and then you press the Save and View Analysis to get your score. If you passed - great! If you failed you will be able to read your detailed feedback which tells you where you were weak. If there is enough time left from the two hour allowance, you can have another go. The two hours is very generous and it means in theory you could have up to four attempts, with feedback provided to you after each attempt so you improve each time.

entry.title: Implications of Functional User license for Contingent workers when using onboarding
entry.content:
In this article we will discuss how a contingent worker is hired as an employee via SuccessFactors Onboarding and how this may affect the functional user license in SuccessFactors.

There are number of ways a user in SuccessFactors Employee Central can be a functional user:

  • They do not have access to SuccessFactors platform i.e. no login permissions in RBP.
  • They are seasonal worker with a length of service lest than 1 year.
  • Their details are mastered in an external HRIS.
  • They are contingent worker.

The full and functional user license only applies to SuccessFactors Employee Central.

A contingent worker will always be a functional user whether they have access to SuccessFactors platform or not.

In the scenario where you have a contingent worker who is ‚Äòconverting‚Äô to an employee, this requires a termination and a hire record.  If you initiate onboarding for the contingent worker, they will complete their onboarding record for their new ‚Äòemployee‚Äô record by switching the employment profile switcher.  Clearly for them to do this they will need access to SuccessFactors.  If they do not have access to SuccessFactors and access is given this WILL NOT switch them to a ‚Äòfull user license‚Äô as they are a contingent worker, and all contingent workers are classified as functional users.

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: SAP TechEd on Tour brought the best out of Berlin, Bengaluru, and Sydney!
entry.content:
As SAP TechEd on Tour continues to inspire people around the world, our SAP community is buzzing with fresh insights, great lessons, and standout contributions from Developer Advocates, SAP Champions and Mentors, and members from local groups. This edition of our newsletter brings you some of the blog posts that dive deeper into the most talked-about topics from SAP TechEd in Berlin, Bengaluru and Sydney. Whether you joined the events in person or are catching up virtually, these resources will help you to keep the innovation energy high and inspired to thrive on the SAP topics. 

Beyond technical content, we‚Äôre also spotlighting the vibrant connections forming at the SAP Community in-person gatherings. From post-sessions reflections to personal stories, these posts reflect the passion and collaboration that make our community grow. We‚Äôre excited to share not only the knowledge but also the experiences and inspiration that emerged through the month of November. So, dive in and keep the momentum going! 

Featured Blog Posts 

Follow-up of the ‚ÄúBest of U15‚Äú demo presented at SAP TechEd in Bengaluru 

One of the highlights of SAP TechEd on Tour was the amazing demos presented by our Community Advocates and Developer Advocates. At the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru last week, Nico Schoenteich demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements. As a follow-up of his demo presented at the Developer Keynote, he published a blog post about how to consume arbitrary web components natively in U15 applications. Either you were on site and are looking for more information or could not attend but are interested in the topic, we highly recommend checking his content for valuable advice to make the process decreasingly complicated. 

Read Nico Schoenteich blog post here 

SAP Integration Suite: guide to secure you integrations and compliance best practices  

Our SAP Community member Praveen Kumar Beera, beyond attending SAP TechEd 2025, also made sure to share more important tips on SAP Integration Suite. On his latest blog post, Praveen dives into how to implement and manage access policies effectively, focusing on the importance of securing your integrations and maintaining robust governance. His step-by-step guide has all the images, examples, and links that you need to understand how to archive a better security setup and reduce risks.  

Read Praveen kumar Beera blog post here 

SAP TechEd on Tour: Sessions using SAP Mobile Start 

SAP Mobile Start is the native entry point to the SAP Business Suite, providing access to native or web-responsive business apps along with other content and critical business information. At SAP TechEd in Berlin and Bengaluru, SAP¬¥s ‚ÄØThilo Berndt and Thomas Bruckner, covered various mobile topics at Workshops called "CA260‚ÄØ‚Äì Learn how to build your own app and use it in SAP Mobile Start". On Thomas‚Äô latest blog post, he shared a full recap with the main technical aspects and valuable material for introduction, building and deploying the base version of the extension, app integration, and extensions, plus the implementation of own push notifications. The on-site sessions were centered on the ease of building pro-code extensions using SAP Build and specifically SAP Build Code with the‚ÄØSAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). And if you could not take part and want to have a chance to try it out, they also uploaded all the material and exercises on GitHub within the repository ‚ÄØSAP-samples/teched2025-CA260.‚ÄØ 

Read Thomas Bruckner blog post here 

Everything you need to know to start with SAP Business Data Cloud 

At SAP TechEd in Sydney, SAP¬¥s Klaus-Peter Sauer presented great sessions around SAP Business Data Cloud, bringing an insightful overview and focusing on growing solutions to the product road map. In case you had the opportunity to watch the session or could not be present, but are looking for more information about the topic, recently one of our SAP community members Akhila Unnithan, published a great BDC Beginner Guide. Akhila shared the main key points to understand how the unified data platform works and how‚ÄØit can turn into the only source that provides everyone with a consistent and governed layer of data, whether it is for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications.‚ÄØShe also explains what are the existing SAP solutions that form the foundation (SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP BW or BW/4HANA) and what are the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP Databricks and SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services). 

Read Akhila Unnithan blog post here 

SAP Community at SAP TechEd on Tour  

SAP TechEd in Berlin: recap by SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi 

‚ÄúSuperheroes without capes‚Äú was the best term the SAP Champion Patrizia Rossi could use to describe our incredible SAP Community team. On her SAP TechEd in Berlin recap blog post, she walks through how the event was one to remember, starting with the fact that she was one of the rewarded SAP Champions on winning the SAP TechEd ticket! With amazing pictures to illustrate the moments at the Developers Keynote and Community Garage, Patrizia explains how she was impacted by the outgrowing Joule Agents and SAP Build, for tangible and smart automations directly from the development environment. Therefore, for her the biggest spark is the fact that AI is no longer an experiment. Patrizia left the event feeling more inspired than ever, and honestly this is the feeling we wish for every single member of our SAP community.  

SAP TechEd in Sydney: connecting before and after 

For a lot of our SAP community members, the connection in-person is the biggest highlight of the SAP TechEd events. And in Sydney, beyond the experience of networking at the Community Garage, the local community made sure to show up also for the pre-event Sydney Stammtisch. Organized by Mike Doyle and Jeff T., the meeting had around 70-80 attendees and plenty of insightful and honest conversations. It was also an incredible opportunity for our SAP Community Advocates, like Anne Petteroe and Josh Bentley, to finally meet in person many local group members and strength even more the connections that were once created online. If you attended and want to share your pictures, comment on Mike latest blog post and share with the community!   

SAP TechEd in Bengaluru: the most energetic and positive crowd  

‚ÄúThe energy, insightful conversations, and knowledge-sharing reaffirmed why this community is so special‚Äú was our SAP Mentor Mohit Bansal description of his participation at the SAP TechEd in Bengaluru, and we also believe that this is the best way to put it. Just like past events, Bengaluru is always a place full of good and high energy people, that are always seeking more innovation, more outcomes, and more real-life connections. Some of our amazing SAP Champions and Mentors could present great sessions, and bring their expertise on-site, creating one of the best atmospheres for learning with purpose. One of the main Key Takeaways for many participants was the accelerating adoption of Business AI worldwide, but also how the complexities of this implementation can only be conquered with the support of all our community. We would like to highly recommend that everyone that was present to share more your experience on a blog post or, in case you are a member of the local community, bring your experience details and pictures at the Bengaluru Location group posts. 

News and Events 

ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville 

Recently one of our biggest events in the United States took place in Louisville, Kentucky, and brought light to many AI improves for developers and business, the constant growth of ABAP, Clean core for digital transformation and many other SAP topics.  SAP¬¥s Peter Spielvogel, wrote an amazing recap (blog post here) with the details of each one of his may Key Notes. But, at ASUG Tech Connect, it was also an opportunity for the local community to come together, to bring together ideas and reflect on the importance of always remembering that people can grow from technological changes. Inspired by the sessions, Peter brought the question on his blog post: ‚ÄûHow can I empower my people by asking them: What are you good at? What do you want? What do you need? What do you fear? This will help you preempt many objections that are rooted in these issues‚Äù, and we also believe that all these are mandatory self-reflecting questions. Did you take part? Do you have any other great thoughts about it? Share with us! 

SAP Webinar Open Source: Efficient Microservices Delivery with Project Konfidence 

This week, on December 4th, the SAP Open Source team is hosting another incredible Webinar again. This edition will be focused on the Project Konfidence, a new open-source that transforms the delivery of microservice-based SaaS applications. The discussion will be held by Sarah M√ºller, engineering manager, and Konfidence project lead at SAP, and Timon Sch√ºle, head of a software delivery framework at SAP, and hosted by Ulrike Fempel, SAP Open Source Program Office. Make sure to watch out for the time according to your time zone: 3pm CET, 9am EST and 7h30pm IST.  Registration link for the event is here and more details about the event on the blog post here.  

Hobbies Series: Long-distance hiking 

We love to see that even with a month full of work like November was for most of us, our community members are still seeking a life balance and taking their time for their passions. The SAP Community Hobbies Series, started by Moshe Naveh, inspired SAP¬¥s Jan Rumig sharing more about his love for hiking over thousands of kilometers. On his latest blog post, he explains that everything began with a family tradition that later became more intense, which he started spending two weeks exploring mountain regions. Illustrating with amazing pictures of his adventures in Portugal, New Zeeland, and Germany, for Jan the most wonderful feeling is when he reaches the final signpost after a long trail. If you are interested in starting to hike, we believe this content will give you the right motivation!

entry.title: Reference Handling in Article Master for Retail
entry.content:
Reference Handling in SAP Retail ‚Äì Key Concepts and Design Considerations

In SAP Retail, reference handling is a foundational principle that supports the effective management of the Article Master. Given the large number of SKUs and the frequency with which new articles are introduced, it becomes essential that reference handling be configured in an optimized and scalable manner. This configuration forms the guiding framework for consistent and efficient article maintenance.

Understanding Reference Handling

When an article is created in the system, multiple tables are updated with various field values. Upstream systems such as PLM may not supply all the necessary information, and several SAP-specific fields must still be maintained for the article to function seamlessly within Retail processes.

Without automation, this can become a significant maintenance burden.

To address this challenge, reference handling is introduced in SAP Retail. Two key elements influence article creation:

  • Reference Articles
  • Reference Sites

Together, these determine how data is inherited and propagated across the article master.

Reference Articles and Variant Behavior

When variant articles are created, the generic article acts as their reference. Any change made to the generic article‚Äîprovided reference handling is active‚Äîis automatically copied to all its variants. This ensures data consistency across the article hierarchy.

When an article is created with a reference article, field values are copied from the reference as default entries. Based on field attributes, these values are proposed during creation and can be updated again whenever the reference object changes. This inheritance occurs across several layers:

  • Values flow from a generic article to its variants
  • Data passes from a reference site to dependent sites
  • Attributes cascade from client-level data to lower validity areas

Article Deviation

If article master data differs from its reference level, it is classified as inconsistent data or an article deviation. The system is designed to automatically realign the data with the reference whenever the article is accessed in update mode.

All deviations are logged in table MABW, and deviations may appear across multiple levels:

  • Basic data
  • Site level
  • Storage location
  • Valuation area
  • Warehouse number
  • Storage type
  • Distribution chain

Deviations can be analyzed using the standard report GET_MABW_STATISTIC, while multiple articles can be evaluated together using ANALYSEMABW (SAP Note 2830363).

System Performance Considerations

A system with a high number of site-specific deviations may encounter performance issues. Large numbers of locks are set when articles are opened, resulting in slow performance during article maintenance. In extreme cases, lock table overflow may occur, triggering error M3 021 (‚ÄúA system error has occurred while locking‚Äù).

Solution Strategy and Design Approach

A reference article acts as a template from which logistics data, valuation parameters, and site-level values are derived. Its purpose is to reduce manual effort, improve data quality, and ensure consistent attributes across the Retail article master.

The definition of Merchandise Category Reference Articles becomes a critical design decision. Choosing whether to use one reference article for all merchandise categories or multiple reference articles should depend on:

  • The number of attributes that must be inherited
  • The degree of variation in field values across merchandise categories

SAP allows a warning to be issued during article creation if no reference article has been assigned to the merchandise category. This control helps ensure that all articles are created with the correct reference framework.

During solution design, if certain site-specific attributes are expected to differ from the reference article, those fields can be excluded from reference handling. In such cases, site-level maintenance must be performed manually during article creation.

Why Article Deviations Should Be Minimized

Article deviations should be avoided because inconsistent data across reference levels can cause unnecessary locks, degrade system performance, and increase ongoing maintenance effort. By keeping article data aligned with its reference values, data integrity is preserved, and system performance is improved.

Conclusion

Optimizing reference handling is a critical aspect of Article Master design in SAP Retail. A well-structured reference strategy ensures consistent data, reduces manual workload, prevents system inefficiencies, and supports scalable, stable Retail operations.

entry.title: Re: How to Preview data of SAP HANA View as other user ?
entry.content:
Hi,
You may try to grant the same privileges as A001 to B001.

To achieve this, you may use following SQL attached in note 1969700. It will generate a list SQLs for you to grant the same privileges and roles to B001.

SQL:HANA_Security_CopyPrivilegesAndRoles_CommandGenerator (SOURCE_GRANTEE = 'A001', TARGET_GRANTEE = 'B001')

PS: Parameters suggested above need to be adapted in /* Modification section */ of corresponding SQLs. Detailed information about how to change parameters in /* Modification section */ can be referred to note 1969700.

Please be aware that you still need use a DB user who has sufficient privilege to grant those roles and privileges to B001.

Best Regards,
Eason Chen

entry.title: S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance custom installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for hostname change and SID change. Also if you want to change instance number the command, screens show where you can change the instance number. This would make sense if your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID. Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

If you want to do standard installation with no change in hostname and sid please refer to other blog In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily.

This blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2023 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51058694_1 to 51058694_5  files and SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51058694_5, SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

WARNING: PLEASE NOTE THE MOUNT POINT ! Since HANA Release 8, if you want to rename the SID, the mount point /hana/data, /hana/log and /hana/shared should be used instead of /hana/data/HDB, /hana/log/HDB and /hana/shared/HDB. Reason is - the hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you. This applies for any other filesystem that contains DB SID, mount its parent directory and only applies to HANA DB. SAP filesystems continue to be mounted with target SID as before. After installation is completed, you can adjust the filesystems mount points if necessary according to your standard to keep it consistent for other systems. 

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 - Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 - Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers
The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below. If you are changing hostname for db and sap add the standard and new hostname for DB but for SAP only provide new hostname. Also for J2E include the new hostname only as this is on separate instance. The standard hostname can be removed later as shown in the steps below. Please note that it has

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51058694_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51058694_1 to 51058694_4) to /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51058694_2/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_3/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_4/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-* .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-* .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4d:/sapmedia/# cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H so if you are changing the SID, then you will have to first extract to SID-S4H and then create links to your own SID like S4D

Then extract the files:
sid-hdd-s4d:/usr/sap #cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat usrsap_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat sapmnt_s4h.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml


Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

The HANA DB hdblcm register_rename_system command will rename the filesystem for you according to the new target SID for Hana database instance. HDB => HDD.

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdd-s4d: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system

TIP: Places where you need to enter data is indicated, rest all are default options. Please note hdblcm now includes rename database host and a separate step with command to rename db host (hdblcm --action=rename_system --hostmap=vhcalhdbdb=vhcalhdddb) is not required. Also a separate step to rename mount points (hdblcm --action=register_rename_system) is not required.

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdd-s4d: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

TIP: At this point it is necessary to install the HANA database license as the database will be started in restricted mode.

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdd-s4d:/install #/sapmnt/S4D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR

STEP 6: RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4dci

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdd-s4d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you dont want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02(or changed number) and Password Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next.

If you don't install HANA DB license you will get error below. Install license using HANA Studio and continue. License is required if there is a database SID change..

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next 

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn
At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button ‚Äì Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next
At next screen Warning click OK
At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next
TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption Key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

(1) Error occurs when executing command 'changekey' using the command line tool 'rsecssfx'.

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

(2) You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/S4D/profile 

After sapinst process is finished you can manually start the SAP instance S4D

sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdd-s4d:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H as well as temporary hostnames.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB ‚Äì Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password> or as you changed in above
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT (nothing was required to be done here).

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC using tcode httpurlloc

Adapt RFC Connections

ABAP connections:
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_RFC
‚Ä¢ S4DCLNT100, S4DCLNT200, S4DCLNT400
‚Ä¢ S4D_RFC

HTTP connections:
‚Ä¢ ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTP
‚Ä¢ LOCAL_HTTPS
‚Ä¢ S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant enter tCode /UI2/FLP_CUS_CONF

Adapt the Fiori notification URL. enter tCode /UI2/FLP_SYS_CONF

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
In SAP S/4HANA 1909 the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system, Change originals to S4D, Delete old TMS config, delete old versions of transport routes

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

The database should be with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.Please carry out the the other basis steps that are usually done with SID change/System refresh :

SPAD - Spool Administration
SCC4 - Client Administration - Logical System
RZ10- Instance profiles
SP01 - Spool delete old spool requests

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

Plan the change of SID, hostname, instance number. Please refer to the notes below for reserved SIDs SAP Note 1979280 ‚Äì Reserved SAP System Identifiers (SAPSID) with Software Provisioning Manager and hostnames SAP Note 611361 ‚Äì Hostnames of SAP ABAP Platform servers

The table below shows standard SID and hostnames and what we are changing it to.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES

Extract files 51058694_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E; /usr/sap/J2E and /sybase/J2E. After these are extracted you can rename the filesystem or remount with changed mount points.

sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-*  | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2d:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: RENAME MOUNT POINTS You can take a full OS backup at this point and rename mount points or directories to /sybase/J2D; /sapmnt/J2D; /usr/sap/J2D. The old standard mount points do not have to exist. After reboot ensure all new renamed mount points are valid.

STEP 5 EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2d:/install #/sapmnt/J2D/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 6 RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2d:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2dci 

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E and Target System J2D:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2d and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the screen Media Browser select the media Package Location and Click on Next

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

After about 10mins, the installation process will stop at this point.

You may get Warning below for rename of profile parameter. Found possible references to the source system in the profile directory of the target system /sapmnt/J2D/profile 

Please take note and proceed.

After the sapinst installation is complete, you can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2D using old startsap / stopsap commands

sid-j2d:/install # su - j2dadm
sid-j2d:j2dadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Administrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2d.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:
JAVA Administrator ‚Äì Adminitstrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome1

STEP 7: POST STEPS Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don‚Äôt install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks
Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID
After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues (2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert ‚Äì S/4HANA

entry.title: Re: LICENSE_EXPIRED Error during S/4 Hana Application Ser...
entry.content:
Hi,

You may refer to following guide for explanation.
License Problem Identification and Analysis
*****
SAP HANA licenses can be installed for the system database (global) or for a single tenant database (local). Global licenses are for the system database and all tenants but a license installed in a tenant will govern only the tenant. If the license is installed incorrectly at the local level you can remove the tenant-specific license key to revert the license validity to the global license key installed in the system database.
*****
Best Regards,
Eason Chen

entry.title: Common Formula Issues in Comp Custom Fields
entry.content:
I learnt Comp implementation(Not VP) mostly by going through the Implementation Guide & SAP Community Blogs. While learning, I began playing around with the demo instance, making up scenarios and solving them. When I started working on my first implementation, I initially thought it would be a cakewalk as I was well trained & worked on multiple support projects.
For my first implementation, I had gone through the full client requirements & started the config. After completing the initial setup, I moved into the Design Worksheet part where I began writing the logics(Formula). That's when I started facing issues simple in hindsight, but at that time they caused panic because the deadline was close. So this blog is the collection for those Formula issues I faced during my first implementation.

1.  In Nested IF statements forgetting to add the "False" result.

A very common mistake is forgetting to add the false result in nested IF formulas.

Basic structure:
if(condition,true,false)

While adding "false" for simple conditions is not an issue, things get messy in multi-layer IFs. Many times, the false part is left out. The formula gets saved even if there is no "False" value but it may behave erratically.

Points to remember:

  • Both trueValue and falseValue must use the same data type.

  • If data types differ, the backend evaluation can fail.

  • Dependent fields might show wrong or inconsistent results.

2. Lookup Tables with Hyphens (‚Äú-‚Äù)

This issue occurs when lookup tables are filled with hyphens to represent blank values. For example:

Grade Merit 
GD-15%
GD-2‚Äì
GD-3‚Äì
GD-42%

There will be no issue if you are just displaying the values in a column but the problem arises when the values flowing from the lookup are used in a formula for calculation, like if you are using the value and performing a mathematical operation on them, the system often returns N/A, because the hyphen can‚Äôt be converted into a number even with toNumber().

Checks :

  • Keep lookup column data types consistent.

  • Hyphens are fine for display-only fields.

  • For calculations, don‚Äôt use hyphens use 0 or keep them blank.

3. Blank Column Check

When checking for empty strings, always compare with ''.
Space inside the quotes ' ' is not empty and the condition will not work.

Incorrect example:
if(Country='INDIA' && Merit=' ','Error','')

Since ' ' contains a space, the check won‚Äôt work.

Solution:

  • Always use '' when checking for empty text.

4. dateDiff Returning ‚ÄúN/A‚Äù

dateDiff fails when the date formats between cust fields and EC fields don‚Äôt match.
Even the formulas like below may still show N/A.:

  • dateDiff(startDate,C_end_date)

  • dateDiff(toDate(startDate,"MM/dd/yyyy"),toDate(C_end_date,"MM/dd/yyyy"))

Solution:

  1. Convert both dates in different columns use the same date format in both columns (Use toDate).

  2. Apply dateDiff() only after ensuring consistent formatting.

5. Troubleshooting Nested IFs and Lookups

For formulas having multiple IF conditions & lookup table references

  • Make sure that both outputs (true/false) have matching data types.

  • Use toNumber() for lookup values when used inside a calculation.

If the formula is still not behaving correctly then:

  • Break the formula into smaller condition.

  • Test each condition one by one.

  • Rather than looking for a issue in a lengthy formula, Its more efficient to break the formula and to test it condition by condition. "Don't look for the needle in the haystack"

6. Column Designer - Working Method

A process that works well during template configuration:

  1. Create reference Excel sheet  based on the client file with all column names and formulas to be configured.

  2. Set up each column based on this reference file.

  3. After testing the logics(Launching the worksheets).

  4. Tweak the column types first.

  5. Make changes in the formula as per the requirements.

  6. Create a validation sheet with Column Name, Column ID, Column Type, Formula(Data Source) and remarks.

  7. If you are comfortable with template XML then, just export the XML and validate it.

7. Debugging Mindset:

Sometimes the issues are right in front of us, but we overlook them. The methods that helped me are,

  • Step away for few minutes.

  • Shift to another configuration or column.

  • Come back with a clear mind.

This small reset often helps in catching mistakes quicker.

Conclusion:

These are the issues related to formula logic that I faced during my first comp implementation. The funny part is that the complex client requirements didn't bother me as much as these issues did. In hindsight, if I had known these beforehand I would have handled them more efficiently. Through these issues, I learnt that problem solving requires patience & focus. I have also faced issues related to budgets, eligibility rules & reward statements. I will be writing about them in the future blogs.

If you've faced similar issues or have better solutions, please share them, I'm always open to learn.

SAP SuccessFactors Compensation

entry.title: Re: Want align baseline date and posting date.
entry.content: To keep the Baseline Date the same as the Posting Date in SAP, you need to adjust the Payment Terms configuration (transaction OBB8 in SPRO). In the payment term settings, set the Baseline Date calculation to Posting Date instead of Document Date or Entry Date. Once updated, invoices and payment runs will consistently align both dates, ensuring the baseline date always matches the posting date.

entry.title: Build a Dynamic Monthly Summary ALV Report in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
Introduction: 

Dynamic ALV reports are essential when your reporting requirements are flexible, and columns or structure are determined at runtime. In this tutorial, we will build a report that: 

  • Summarizes data by year and month. 
  • Creates dynamic columns for Posting, Expenditure, and GRN. 
  • Displays results in an ALV grid dynamically. 

This approach uses RTTS (Run-Time Type Services) to build dynamic tables and structures at runtime. 

Step 1: Define Types, Parameters, Data Declarations, and Field symbols. 

  • Parameters allow users to select year (GJAHR) and starting month (MONAT). 
  • Field symbols and generic data references make the table dynamic at runtime. 
  • RTTS objects (cl_abap_structdescr, cl_abap_elemdescr) are initialized here. 
* TABLES
TABLES: zposting_data.
* TYPES
TYPES: ty_yyyymm TYPE c LENGTH 6.
* PARAMETERS
PARAMETERS:
  p_gjahr TYPE zposting_data-gjahr,
  p_monat TYPE zposting_data-monat.
* DATA DECLARATIONS
DATA:
  gt_source_data   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zposting_data,
  gt_months        TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_yyyymm,

  go_salv_table    TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table,
  gr_dynamic_table TYPE REF TO data,
  gr_dynamic_line  TYPE REF TO data,

  go_struct_descr  TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
  gt_components    TYPE cl_abap_structdescr=>component_table,
  gs_component     TYPE abap_componentdescr.

* FIELD-SYMBOLS
FIELD-SYMBOLS:
  <gt_dyn_table>   TYPE STANDARD TABLE,
  <gs_dyn_line>    TYPE any,
  <gfs_field>      TYPE any.

Step 1.2: Declare START-OF-SELECTION. 

* START-OF-SELECTION

START-OF-SELECTION.
  PERFORM get_source_data.
  PERFORM determine_unique_months.
  PERFORM create_dynamic_table_structure.
  PERFORM populate_dynamic_table.
  PERFORM display_alv.

Step 2: Fetch Data from Database 

  • Use a simple SELECT statement to fetch posting data for the selected year. 
  • If no data exists, gracefully exit with a message. 
FORM get_source_data .
SELECT *
    FROM zposting_data
    INTO TABLE @gt_source_data
    WHERE gjahr = @p_gjahr
    ORDER BY gjahr, monat.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'No data found for selected year' TYPE 'I'.
    LEAVE PROGRAM.
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.
  • Step 3: Determine Unique Months. 
    Loop through source data and pick months greater than or equal to the selected start month. 
  • Use SORT and DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES to ensure unique months only. 
FORM determine_unique_months .
  LOOP AT gt_source_data INTO DATA(ls_src).
    IF ls_src-monat >= p_monat.
      DATA(lv_yyyymm) = |{ ls_src-gjahr }{ ls_src-monat }|.
      APPEND lv_yyyymm TO gt_months.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
  SORT gt_months.
  DELETE ADJACENT DUPLICATES FROM gt_months.
ENDFORM.

Step 4: Create Dynamic Table Structure 

  • Use RTTS to create dynamic columns at runtime. 
  • Add static summary columns and dynamic month columns for Posting, Expenditure, and GRN. 
  • Column names are dynamically generated using month abbreviations (JAN, FEB, etc.). 
FORM create_dynamic_table_structure .
  DATA(lo_struct) = cl_abap_typedescr=>describe_by_name( 'ZPOSTING_DATA' ).
  DATA(lo_comp)   = CAST cl_abap_structdescr( lo_struct )->get_components( ).
  CLEAR gs_component.
  gs_component-name = 'REPORT_SUMMARY'.
  gs_component-type ?= cl_abap_elemdescr=>get_c( 50 ).
  APPEND gs_component TO gt_components.
  DATA lv_abbr   TYPE c LENGTH 3.
  LOOP AT gt_months INTO DATA(lv_yyyymm).
    DATA(lv_month) = lv_yyyymm+4(2).
     CASE lv_month.
      WHEN '01'. lv_abbr = 'JAN'.
      WHEN '02'. lv_abbr = 'FEB'.
      WHEN '03'. lv_abbr = 'MAR'.
      WHEN '04'. lv_abbr = 'APR'.
      WHEN '05'. lv_abbr = 'MAY'.
      WHEN '06'. lv_abbr = 'JUN'.
      WHEN '07'. lv_abbr = 'JUL'.
      WHEN '08'. lv_abbr = 'AUG'.
      WHEN '09'. lv_abbr = 'SEP'.
      WHEN '10'. lv_abbr = 'OCT'.
      WHEN '11'. lv_abbr = 'NOV'.
      WHEN '12'. lv_abbr = 'DEC'.
    ENDCASE.
    CLEAR gs_component.
    gs_component-name = |{ lv_abbr }_POSTING|.
    gs_component-type ?= cl_abap_elemdescr=>get_i( ).
    APPEND gs_component TO gt_components.
    CLEAR gs_component.
    gs_component-name = |{ lv_abbr }_EXP|.
    gs_component-type ?= cl_abap_datadescr=>describe_by_name( 'ZPOSTING_DATA-EXPENDITURE' ).
    APPEND gs_component TO gt_components.
    CLEAR gs_component.
    gs_component-name = |{ lv_abbr }_GRN|.
    gs_component-type ?= cl_abap_elemdescr=>get_i( ).
    APPEND gs_component TO gt_components.
  ENDLOOP.
  go_struct_descr ?= cl_abap_structdescr=>create( gt_components ).
  DATA(lo_table_descr) = cl_abap_tabledescr=>create( go_struct_descr ).
  CREATE DATA gr_dynamic_table TYPE HANDLE lo_table_descr.
  ASSIGN gr_dynamic_table->* TO <gt_dyn_table>.
  CREATE DATA gr_dynamic_line LIKE LINE OF <gt_dyn_table>.
  ASSIGN gr_dynamic_line->* TO <gs_dyn_line>.
ENDFORM.

Step 5: Populate Dynamic Table 

  • Assign values to dynamic columns using ASSIGN COMPONENT ‚Ä¶ OF STRUCTURE. 
  • Aggregates Posting, Expenditure, and GRN month-wise. 
  • Static summary column is filled with a yearly summary text. 
  • Finally, append the populated line to the dynamic table. 
FORM populate_dynamic_table.
CLEAR <gs_dyn_line>.
  UNASSIGN <gfs_field>.
  ASSIGN COMPONENT 'REPORT_SUMMARY' OF STRUCTURE <gs_dyn_line> TO <gfs_field>.
  IF <gfs_field> IS ASSIGNED.
    <gfs_field> = |Summary for { p_gjahr }|.
  ENDIF.
    DATA lv_abbr TYPE c LENGTH 3.
  LOOP AT gt_source_data INTO DATA(ls_src).
     CASE ls_src-monat.
      WHEN '01'. lv_abbr = 'JAN'.
      WHEN '02'. lv_abbr = 'FEB'.
      WHEN '03'. lv_abbr = 'MAR'.
      WHEN '04'. lv_abbr = 'APR'.
      WHEN '05'. lv_abbr = 'MAY'.
      WHEN '06'. lv_abbr = 'JUN'.
      WHEN '07'. lv_abbr = 'JUL'.
      WHEN '08'. lv_abbr = 'AUG'.
      WHEN '09'. lv_abbr = 'SEP'.
      WHEN '10'. lv_abbr = 'OCT'.
      WHEN '11'. lv_abbr = 'NOV'.
      WHEN '12'. lv_abbr = 'DEC'.
    ENDCASE.
    DATA(lv_post) = |{ lv_abbr }_POSTING|.
    DATA(lv_exp)  = |{ lv_abbr }_EXP|.
    DATA(lv_grn)  = |{ lv_abbr }_GRN|.
    " POST
    UNASSIGN <gfs_field>.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_post OF STRUCTURE <gs_dyn_line> TO <gfs_field>.
    IF <gfs_field> IS ASSIGNED.
      <gfs_field> = <gfs_field> + ls_src-posting_cnt.
    ENDIF.
    " EXP
    UNASSIGN <gfs_field>.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_exp OF STRUCTURE <gs_dyn_line> TO <gfs_field>.
    IF <gfs_field> IS ASSIGNED.
      <gfs_field> = <gfs_field> + ls_src-expenditure.
    ENDIF.
    " GRN
    UNASSIGN <gfs_field>.
    ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_grn OF STRUCTURE <gs_dyn_line> TO <gfs_field>.
    IF <gfs_field> IS ASSIGNED.
      <gfs_field> = <gfs_field> + ls_src-grn_count.
    ENDIF.
  ENDLOOP.
  APPEND <gs_dyn_line> TO <gt_dyn_table>.
ENDFORM.

Step 6: Display Dynamic ALV 

  • Use CL_SALV_TABLE to display the dynamic table. 
  • Optimize column widths using set_optimize( abap_true ). 
  • Add descriptive long texts for each dynamic column for readability. 
  • Exception handling ensures that the program doesn‚Äôt dump even if ALV fails. 
FORM display_alv .
  TRY.
      cl_salv_table=>factory(
        IMPORTING
          r_salv_table = go_salv_table
        CHANGING
          t_table      = <gt_dyn_table>
      ).
      DATA(lo_cols) = go_salv_table->get_columns( ).
      lo_cols->set_optimize( abap_true ).
DATA lv_abbr   TYPE c LENGTH 3.
      LOOP AT gt_months INTO DATA(lv_yyyymm).
        DATA(lv_m) = lv_yyyymm+4(2).
         CASE lv_m.
          WHEN '01'. lv_abbr = 'JAN'.
          WHEN '02'. lv_abbr = 'FEB'.
          WHEN '03'. lv_abbr = 'MAR'.
          WHEN '04'. lv_abbr = 'APR'.
          WHEN '05'. lv_abbr = 'MAY'.
          WHEN '06'. lv_abbr = 'JUN'.
          WHEN '07'. lv_abbr = 'JUL'.
          WHEN '08'. lv_abbr = 'AUG'.
          WHEN '09'. lv_abbr = 'SEP'.
          WHEN '10'. lv_abbr = 'OCT'.
          WHEN '11'. lv_abbr = 'NOV'.
          WHEN '12'. lv_abbr = 'DEC'.
        ENDCASE.
        lo_cols->get_column( |{ lv_abbr }_POSTING| )->set_long_text( |{ lv_abbr } Posting Count| ).
        lo_cols->get_column( |{ lv_abbr }_EXP|     )->set_long_text( |{ lv_abbr } Expenditure| ).
        lo_cols->get_column( |{ lv_abbr }_GRN|     )->set_long_text( |{ lv_abbr } GRN Count| ).
      ENDLOOP.
      go_salv_table->display( ).
    CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx_msg).
      MESSAGE lx_msg->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

Input (Example) 

Output  (Example)

entry.title: Smarter Warehouse Execution with Work Distribution and Task Bundling
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced logistics world, efficiency in warehouse operations determines how quickly and accurately businesses can deliver to their customers. But selecting, assigning, and executing hundreds of individual warehouse tasks each day can be time-consuming and complex.

To address these challenges, SAP Logistics Management is introducing two new capabilities designed to bring efficiency to warehouse execution: Work Distribution and Task Bundling.

These new functions will simplify task execution, streamline workload, and help warehouse colleagues work together more effectively.

 

A Step Toward More Efficient Warehouse Operations

Every movement in a warehouse ‚Äî whether inbound, outbound, or internal ‚Äî creates one or more warehouse tasks. Today, these tasks are handled individually. Warehouse operatives must manually select one by task ID. This manual approach often leads to inefficiencies: repeated travel between similar storage bins, and unnecessary waiting times during warehouse processing.

Logistics Management‚Äôs new capabilities are designed to change that, making warehouse execution smarter, faster, and more guided.

 

How Work Distribution and Task Bundling Work Together

Bundle the right warehouse tasks together and distribute them via work queues.

Process Warehouse Tasks Application

Warehouse Task Bundling

Instead of handling each task individually, warehouse task bundling allows several related tasks to be combined and executed as one group.

For example:

  • When picking items for a single customer order, all related tasks can be performed together, avoiding later consolidation at the packing station.
  • Tasks from similar source bins can be grouped to minimize travel time.

This not only saves effort but also ensures a more structured and efficient workflow for warehouse operatives.

Process Warehouse Tasks Application

Work Distribution

After tasks are bundled, the next step is to make sure they are executed by the right warehouse operatives. This is where Work Distribution comes into play.

Logistics clerks organize warehouse tasks and bundles by placing them into work queues. Once tasks or bundles are in a work queue, warehouse operatives can log in, view the available tasks, and receive the ones they are ready to work on.

This approach ensures that tasks are distributed in a controlled and efficient way, giving operatives clear visibility of their work while allowing clerks to manage workloads.

Process Warehouse Tasks Application

 

End-to-End Process on Mobile

These capabilities are deeply connected to the Logistics Management mobile app, which ensures that tasks within a bundle are processed together as planned.

Warehouse operatives will be able to see their assigned tasks directly on their mobile devices. This system-guided approach minimizes manual navigation and helps the operatives execute work efficiently, with fewer errors and less downtime.

Meanwhile, logistics clerks will have clearer visibility into workload distribution and progress, allowing them to make adjustments when needed.

 

Driving Efficiency and Collaboration

By combining Work Distribution and Warehouse Task Bundling, warehouse operatives benefit from guided, system-supported execution, while logistics clerks can manage workloads in a structured and transparent way.

As these capabilities evolve, they will form the foundation for future automation. In the initial release, logistics clerks will manually manage how tasks and bundles are grouped into queues and released to operatives. In upcoming releases, automation will dynamically assign tasks based on business rules and real-time conditions ‚Äî such as priority, equipment requirements, or worker location ‚Äî ensuring balanced workloads and even higher operational efficiency across the warehouse.

 

Call to Action

Your questions and comments are welcome! Please share your feedback and thoughts in a comment.

Follow me on the SAP Community to stay up to date!

If you are interested in Logistics Management‚Äôs other services, I recommend you read Logistics Management Help Document, and your questions will be answered here.
